message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive monospot test suggest that the patient is most likely infected with Epstein-Barr virus, which is the cause of infectious mononucleosis. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, exudative tonsillitis, and positive monospot test together suggest a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which is primarily caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Varicella virus causes chickenpox, Cytomegalovirus causes a variety of illnesses, and Variola virus causes smallpox, none of which are consistent with the symptoms and presentation of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive monospot test suggest that the patient is most likely infected with Epstein-Barr virus, which causes infectious mononucleosis. The other options are not known to cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive monospot test suggest that the patient is most likely infected with Epstein-Barr virus, which is commonly associated with mononucleosis. The other options are not associated with mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, age of the patient, and positive monospot test suggest that the most likely cause is Epstein-Barr virus. The other viruses are less commonly associated with sore throats or not associated with sore throats at all.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including cervical lymphadenopathy and a positive monospot test, suggest that the patient is most likely infected with Epstein-Barr virus. Variola virus causes smallpox which is no longer present in humans. Cytomegalovirus and Varicella virus usually do not cause pharyngitis with tonsillar exudate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A positive monospot test suggests Epstein-Barr virus as the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. The other options are not associated with mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and cervical lymphadenopathy suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is most commonly caused by Epstein-Barr virus. The positive monospot test also supports this diagnosis. Variola virus causes smallpox, cytomegalovirus can cause mononucleosis-like symptoms but is less common in this age group, and varicella virus causes chickenpox or shingles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, positive monospot test, and presence of cervical lymphadenopathy suggest an infection with Epstein-Barr virus, which is the most common cause of infectious mononucleosis. Variola virus is the virus that causes smallpox, which has been eradicated. Cytomegalovirus can cause similar symptoms but is less common in adolescents, and varicella virus causes chickenpox.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the positive Monospot test suggest an Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection. Variola virus causes smallpox, Cytomegalovirus is not typically associated with tonsillar exudate, and Varicella virus causes chickenpox.
